Dialogue: Demolition, right?

Dialogue: No kidding.

Dialogue: You'll grieve the way I tell you to goddamned grieve.  There is no Wade, there was one, but he died a long time ago, he's been dead for so long you can hardly remember his name, you understand?

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Sir, I understand.  I don't like it, but I understand.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Good, now get your goddamned gear.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: You know what the best possible thing that could happen is?

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Yep, you step on a rusty nail, get lockjaw, never say another word as long as you live.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: I've given this a lot of thought, sir.  The best thing that could happen is, we find Ryan and he's dead.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Why's that?

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Well, sir, consider the possibilities. A:  Ryan is alive.  We have to take him back to the beach.  Knowing you, you don't let him carry my gear, even though he really should, and we all get killed, trying to keep him alive.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Except for the last part, that one's not bad.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: B:  Ryan is dead.  He's been blown up by the German equivalent of Wade, whose name I know you don't want me to mention.  There's nothing to find. The biggest piece is the size of a pea.  We wander around, looking for him until the Germans pick us off, one after another.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: I don't like that one.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Neither do I, sir.  C:  And this is the worst one, we find Ryan and he's wounded.  Not only does he not carry my gear, we have to carry his gear. And him.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: But we accomplish the mission.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Maybe.  But what if he dies on the way back?  you see what I'm saying, sir?  The best possible situation is, he's dead, we find his body, more or less intact, we grab one of his dog-tags and high-tail it back to the beach, or better yet, we head over to Caen and catch up with division.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Has anyone ever told you, you're officer material?

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: No, sir.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: That's a mystery to me.

Speaker: sarge
Dialogue: Looks like we're going to beat those Kraut companies to Ramelle.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: I don't think so.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Is just about to open up on them.

Speaker: upham
Dialogue: I wonder where they're going.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Same place we are.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Scans the Germans with his binoculars.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Looks like tea time, maybe they're Brits.

Speaker: upham
Dialogue: I sure hope so.

Speaker: sarge
Dialogue: What do you think they're waiting for, Captain?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Puts away the binoculars and jerks his head for his men to follow, low, along the wall.  The men are happy to do so, looking back nervously at the German tanks.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Looks like they've been having a hell of a party, here, Captain.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: ON THE BRIDGE!  WE'RE COMING IN.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: YOU FIRE AT US AND I'LL DO A HELL OF A LOT MORE THAN THAT.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: I HAVE NO FUCKING IDEA.  HERE WE COME.  Cover me.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: What if our guys open up, sir?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: You're only allowed to shoot at Germans, that's one of the rules.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Have it your way, Captain.

Speaker: miller's men
Dialogue: POUR FIRE at the German positions, SURPRESSING THE GERMAN FIRE.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: I'll keep it in mind.  OKAY, SARGE, ONE AT A TIME.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Things are tough all over.  We're looking for a Private James Ryan.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Is he here?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Jackson, get a hold of command.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: How many men do you have?

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Not yet.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Keep trying.

Speaker: miller's men
Dialogue: All watch Ryan run toward them.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: So, that's Ryan.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Looks like a flaming asshole to me.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: I'm Ryan, sir.  You wanted to see me?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: the paratroopers
Dialogue: Are stunned at the news.  They look at Ryan, there's nothing else they can do.

Speaker: miller's men
Dialogue: Also look at Ryan, but then, one after another, they turn away, adverting their eyes, looking a their own boots, the debris on the bridge, the sky, anything other than Ryan.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: We've been sent to get you out of here.  You're going home.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Sergeant, we're moving out and I'm taking you and your men with me.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: I'm giving you new orders, Sergeant.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: I'm not going to leave you and your men here to get killed.  Get them together, we're moving out.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Come on, Private, you're going home.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: No, sir.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Private.  I'm sorry about your brothers but staying here and getting yourself killed isn't going to help.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Sir, if the Krauts are holding this bridge when division shows up, our guys are going to be sitting ducks.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: This bridge cannot be held.  The Germans have two companies less than three miles from here.  They have tanks.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Private, if you want to commit suicide, that's your choice, but you're going to have to wait until after I get you back to the beach. And you're not going to take these men with you.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'm not leaving, sir.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: The hell you aren't, you're comin' with me if I have to drag you every inch of the way.  You hear me, Private?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I hear you sir, but I'm not leaving.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Listen you little son-of-a-bitch you're coming with me or I'll...I'll...

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: What are you going to do, sir, shoot me?

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Uh, excuse me, Captain.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: So, what are a few tanks, sir?

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: He's right, we can't shoot him...well, we could but we'd get in an enormous amount of trouble.  And he's right about the bridge, it's a hell of a lot more important than he is.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Cap'n...?

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Seems to me, we got us a opportunity, here, to kill two birds with one stone.  Command seems to think keepin' this boy alive is worth somethin'. If we was to do that and hold this bridge, good chance we'd get us a bucket full of medals.  I might even get me one 'a them big, fancy ones like you got, so's I could sass any officer in the whole dang army, you included.

Speaker: upham
Dialogue: I'd like to stay, too, Captain.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: You don't count.

Speaker: sarge
Dialogue: I do and personally, I'd rather get the hell out of here, but somebody's got to stay and take care of you and these pin-head privates of yours.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: See, Captain?  The vote's unanimous.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Yes, sir, of course, sir, I was merely speaking hypothetically.  IF this was a voting situation, then the vote would have been unanimous.  But of course, it's not a voting situation, you're the captain, and you give the orders, sir.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: You're goddamned right, I give the order.  Vote!  Jesus Christ!  Listen to me, you little pissant pieces of shit, I am the ranking officer here and what I say goes, is that clear?

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Of course, sir.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: In that case...  I vote we stay.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Reiben, the B.A.R., there.  Jackson, get up on the bridgekeepers hut with your sniper rifle.  Sarge, you and Upham move that machine gun so it can cover the left flank, it's worthless where it is.  Forrest, I want a full inventory of all your weapons, ammo and ordnance.  Go.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Thank you, sir.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Yeah, yeah.  I want you right next to me, no matter where I go, you understand?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Alright, come with me.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: That's it?

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Sir, can I change my vote?

Speaker: upham
Dialogue: Sits beside Jackson with a pair of binoculars, searching for another target.  The German sniper fire has subsided for now.  Ext. bridge - day Miller watches as Ryan and several other paratroopers dig a series of trenches across the street, leading to the bridge.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Sarge, see what you can do to make those buildings inhospitable.

Speaker: sarge
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: upham
Dialogue: Eighty-eights, right?

Speaker: upham
Dialogue: I can tell what the gunners had for dinner.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Those guns are close.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Let's hope they don't change their mind.

Speaker: sarge
Dialogue: What do you think?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Well, if we had ten times the men and a lot more ammo, we might stand a chance, but not against those tanks.

Speaker: sarge
Dialogue: What are we going to do?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: We're going to hope like hell the tanks were on their way somewhere else.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Maybe Caen.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Let's hope, because we're sure as hell not going to do any damage to them with what we have here.

Speaker: upham
Dialogue: What about our grenades?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Those are Tigers, they have six-inch armor, they don't even notice grenades.

Speaker: upham
Dialogue: Would they notice and eighty-eight?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Sure, you got one?

Speaker: upham
Dialogue: The Germans do.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Upham, go find Jackson, he and I are going hunting.

Speaker: sarge
Dialogue: Uh, oh.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Out of the mouth of babes.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Upham, you've got to learn the difference between whining and griping.  You can't just rely on natural ability, you've got to study and practice.

Speaker: upham
Dialogue: But, sir...

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: There you go again, that's whining, that's not okay.

Speaker: upham
Dialogue: Goddamn it, sir...

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: That's better, but you've still got a long way to go.  Talk to Reiben, he's a natural and works at it, he'll give you some pointers.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Leave him to me, Captain, I'll have him pissing and moaning with the best of us.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: See to it.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'd like to go, sir.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: No, private, I want you to stay here, keep your head down, don't do anything brave or stupid.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Aren't they the same thing, sir?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Reiben, I don't know what I'd do without you.  Sarge, keep Ryan close to you and alive.

Speaker: sarge
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: You ready?

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: You betcha, sir.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Y'all come back.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Reiben, are you makin' fun 'a the way I talk?

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Hell, no!

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Eyes the emplacement.  Looks for a weakness.  There is none.  He motions to Forrest and Jackson to wait.  The three of them settle into the darkness.

Speaker: sarge
Dialogue: Private, I'm sorry about your brothers.

Speaker: sarge
Dialogue: Wade.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Wade.  Huh, he died coming up here to keep me alive...I never met him...he didn't know me from Adam, strange.  What was he like?

Speaker: sarge
Dialogue: A good man, kind of cheerful, Reiben, here, used to call him a happy idiot.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Like hell, I did.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: My brothers would be mighty pissed off at me, if they knew I let some guy get killed trying to keep me alive.

Speaker: sarge
Dialogue: You didn't let anybody get killed, you didn't even know we were coming up here.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Sure, I know, but...  Goddamn it all...

Speaker: a shadow
Dialogue: It's Miller.  Easing through the darkness.  Closer to one of the sentries.

Speaker: other germans
Dialogue: Race over, FIRING.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Covering them, OPENS UP.  Kills the advancing Germans.

Speaker: the windshield
Dialogue: Is shattered by bullets.

Speaker: forrest
Dialogue: In the back of the truck.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: RYAN!  GET BACK THERE!

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Sorry, sir.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Don't do that again.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I won't need to sir, it's already here, behind the barricade so...

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: What do you think?

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: I think I'm we got that eighty-eight.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: I mean, Ryan, what do you think of him?

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: He ain't half-bad, I guess.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: I guess.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: He ain't Wade.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Nope, he ain't Wade.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Crouch-runs through the shadows and stops at the bridgekeepers hut.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Reiben...

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: You set?  Sarge nods.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Behind the sandbags, on top of the bridgekeeper's hut.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: At the bridgehead, waiting.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Cocks his Thompson.  Settles down behind some sandbags.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: HERE THEY COME!

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: OPENS UP with the MACHINE GUN.

Speaker: the germans
Dialogue: At least fifty of them, advancing on the bridge.  Running from cover to cover.  A squad pushing a French truck, using it as a shield.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Calmly picking off the attacking Germans.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Sees Reiben and Upham being cut off. Grabs the B.A.R., stands and fires.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Time to go.

Speaker: germans everywhere
Dialogue: They swarm over the first barricade.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: FIRES A BURST into a German's belly. HITS another with the stock of his Thompson.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Is jumped on by one.  Upham FIRES. KILLS the German.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Struggling with a pair of Germans.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: FIRES.  Drops one of the Germans on Miller with a head shot.  Cuts open Miller's face with bits of skull.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Leaps onto the final German attacking Miller.  That German raises his rifle on Ryan.

Speaker: upham
Dialogue: I got him.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Like hell you did, I got him.

Speaker: jackson smiles
Dialogue: He got him.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: BACK!  LET'S GO!

Speaker: sarge
Dialogue: Sees them in deep trouble.  Leaves Ryan firing the rear machine gun. Grabs the B.A.R. ADVANCES, FIRING COVER.  Exposed.

Speaker: bullets everywhere
Dialogue: MILLER, REIBEN, UPHAM make it to the barricade.  Dive over.

Speaker: sarge
Dialogue: Sees they've made it.  FIRES A FINAL BURST.  Races for cover.  A trail of bullets right behind him.

Speaker: the americans
Dialogue: Desperately trying to cover him.

Speaker: the germans
Dialogue: Open up with a volley.

Speaker: sarge
Dialogue: Is almost there.

Speaker: sarge
Dialogue: Five feet from the sandbags, his back is TORN APART by Germans fire. He looks down, stunned at his chest. Amazed to see GAPING HOLES.  An instant of surprise, more than fear.

Speaker: the germans
Dialogue: Who killed Sarge are killed.  The others back off for now.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Grabs Sarge and pulls him over the barricade.  Sees that he's dead.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Stunned, lays Sarge down, kneeling next to him.

Speaker: the others
Dialogue: Watch, start to gather.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Goddamn it...Goddamn it...Goddamn it...

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Get back to your positions!

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Go!

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Doesn't move.  He just stares at Sarge's body.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Looks at Miller, sees him growing weak, starting to sway.  He gently tries to move Miller aside.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'll take care of Sarge...

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Sarge?  Who's Sarge?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: English teacher, Addley, Pennsylvania.

Speaker: upham
Dialogue: What'd you say, Captain?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: I teach English at Addley High School in Addley, Pennsylvania.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Well, I'll be goddamned, I knew it.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Like hell, you did.

Speaker: upham
Dialogue: Captain, what about our deal?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: I changed my mind.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: What deal?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: I coach the baseball team, too.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: No kiddin'?

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: What deal?

Speaker: upham
Dialogue: Forget it.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: You know that cruise ship Wade's grandfather was on?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: I wonder if his cabin is still available?

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: That's not where I am.  Miller No? Where are you?

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: I'm in a dressing room with Mrs. Rachel Troubowitz, our super's wife. She's an easy forty-four, double E, but I've convinced her she's a thirty- eight D and I'm watching her try and squeeze herself into a side-stay, silk-ribboned, three-panel girdle with s Helf-lift brassiere.  She's having a devil of a time, getting into that thing.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Me?  I'm walking with my hound, Lucy, it's about an hour 'fore sunrise and we're out huntin' coon.  I got me a flask of pure Kentucky mash whiskey...

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Jackson, how many times I got to tell you, you're from Tennessee.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: I am, but I like imported whiskey. So there I am and I hear the biggest ole' coon you ever did hear, 'a rustlin' right there in front of me. That ole' boy comes right out of the brush, I got a clear shot and he knows he's 'bout to meet his maker. I aim, I got my finger tight on the trigger and then I just smile and say to that ole' coon, go on, now, you get out 'a here.  Then I sit down on a hollow log and take me a right long pull a' that mash whiskey.

Speaker: upham
Dialogue: I don't know, I kind of like Wade's idea about the cruise ship.  I've never been to Tahiti.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: What about you, Captain?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: I'm in my backyard, lying in my hammock, with my arm around my wife, listening for the sound of breaking glass.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Say what, Cap'n?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: You see, I've got the best house in all of Addley.  It's not the biggest house, but it's got the best location, right next to the junior high baseball field.  The garage windows face left field.  The guy who owned the house before me had these heavy screen S put over them.  The first thing I did when I bought the place was take off those screens.  Two-hundred-twenty- two yards from home plate to my garage windows.  It takes a hell of a junior high kid to hit a ball that far.  I look at my garage windows as a Motivator and a way to scout the kids coming up, the ones who are going to give us a shot at the state championship.  I lay there in my hammock and every time I hear the sound of breaking glass, I know we're one step closer to winning it all.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Don't that get kind of expensive, Cap'n?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: It's worth it.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: To each, his own.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: How about you, James?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'm home, playing basketball with my brothers, it's evenin' time, we're trying' to get in a few more points before it's too dark to see the ball. That's where I am.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Hears the FAINT DISTANT RUMBLE OF THE TANK.  Barely has time to react. Sees:

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Here they come.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: FIRES a burst.  Germans drops.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: FIRES a burst.  More Germans drop.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Manning the forward machine gun. Way out front.  Sees that he's going to be cut off.  He grabs the hot gun.  The barrel burns into his flesh. He ignores the pain and RUNS BACK toward the bridge.

Speaker: the germans
Dialogue: Take positions near the bridge. Moving in.  FIRING.  Overwhelming. They're everywhere.

Speaker: three germans
Dialogue: Break through the perimeter.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Sees Ryan.  Races over.  SHOOTS one German.  STABS the other.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: FIRES again.  More Germans drop.

Speaker: the germans
Dialogue: Take positions in the building near the bridge.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: MORE AMMO!

Speaker: upham
Dialogue: Hears that.  Doesn't hesitate.  He grabs a pair of ammo boxes.  RUNS toward Reiben and Ryan.

Speaker: upham
Dialogue: TAKES HALF-A-DOZEN SLUGS.  Torn apart. Stumbles the final few steps to the machine gun nest.  Falls on the sandbags, giving Reiben and Ryan the ammo.  UPHAM'S DEAD.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Continues FIRING.  CUTTING DOWN the advancing Germans.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Knows what that means.  He hears the RUMBLE OF THE TANKS.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: TIGHTEN IT UP!  HERE THEY COME!

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: On the bridgekeeper's hut.  Picking off German soldiers who follow the tank.

Speaker: the tank
Dialogue: Stops.  Grinds its gears.  Turning it's turret towards the bridgekeepers hut.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: JACKSON!

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Knows what's coming but he holds his position, continuing to pick off German soldiers.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Shoves the FINAL SHELL into the breech of the eighty-eight.  Pats Ryan on the back.  Grabs a SATCHEL CHARGE.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: FIRES THE EIGHTY-EIGHT.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Races through the debris.  Trailed by BULLETS.

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: With the machine gun.  Covers Miller. Keeping most of the German infantry down.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Is almost there.  He arms the satchel charge.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Throws the satchel charge under the tank.  Rolls off the edge of the bridge.  Lands on the embankment below.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: HOLD IT!  HOLD IT!

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Goddamn it!

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: More tanks...  Ryan Lot's of them The fear on their faces turns to resignation.  They know that they are dead men.  They settle into their positions, and prepare to fire and die.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Miller, Company B, Second Rangers, that's Private Richard Reiben and that's Private James Ryan, Hundred- and-First Airborne.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: Ryan?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Walks to the bodies.  He kneels down next to Sarge and looks at him for a long moment.  Then, with a steady hand, he takes one of Sarge's two dog-tags.  Then he does the same to Jackson and Upham.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Stands and walks back to Reiben and Ryan.  He hands the dog-tags to Ryan who grips them tightly and nods in thanks.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Captain?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Yes, Private.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Upham and Jackson, what were they like?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Upham?  Good kid, smart, he was writing a book.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: reiben
Dialogue: Yeah, and he was fast, too, ran the 220 in twenty-four-five.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: No kidding.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Jackson was from West Fork, Tennessee, he was going to be a preacher, his father and uncles have a traveling ministry out of the back of a stretch Hudson.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: And Sarge?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Sarge?  Lemme tell you about Sarge...
